rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;986be687.1503">   <title>Re: Healthcare expenditure in the Developing World </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;986be687.1503</link>   <description> Max,<br>Both public and private expenditure grow as GDP grows.<br>However, as countries get richer, the proportion of private expenditure<br>relative to the total decreases. See graphic.<br>Reference is Gottrett, Shieber, World Bank 2006 (link below)<br>rgds,<br>April<br>[image: Inline image 1]<br><br>Health Financing Revisited : A Practitioner's Guide, Gottrett, Schieber<br>&lt;https://openknowledge.worldbank.org/handle/10986/7094&gt;<br><br>On Tue, Mar 10, 2015 at 12:26 PM, Max Hotopf &lt;max@healthcareeuropa.com&gt;<br>wrote: [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T17:00:51-04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>April Harding</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;986be687.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;612b39f4.1503">   <title>Re: Healthcare expenditure in the Developing World </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;612b39f4.1503</link>   <description> Dear Max,<br>David Evans (in cc) has recently done some work on this issue<br>http://www.chathamhouse.org/sites/files/chathamhouse/public/Research/Global%20Health/0513_healthfinance.pdf<br>Best wishes,<br>Fabrizio<br><br>--<br>Fabrizio Tediosi, MSc, PhD<br>Department of Institutional Analysis and Public Management<br>Centre for Research on Health and Social Care Management (CERGAS)<br>Universit\ufffd\ufffd Bocconi<br>Room 2C1-08, Via Roentgen 1, 20136 Milano<br>Tel. 02 5836-2767<br><br>----- Messaggio originale -----<br><br>Da: &quot;Max Hotopf&quot; &lt;max@HEALTHCAREEUROPA.COM&gt;<br>A: EHPG@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Inviato: Marted\ufffd\ufffd, 10 marzo 2015 17:26:53<br>Oggetto: Healthcare expenditure in the Developing World [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T20:12:30+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Fabrizio Tediosi</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;612b39f4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;522a42a0.1503">   <title>Healthcare expenditure in the Developing World </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;522a42a0.1503</link>   <description> I wonder whether anyone has done any work on how far the increase in GDP in<br>developing countries correlates with an increase in healthcare spending.<br>Can we state any rough rule of thumb (yes I know that is setting off many<br>academic red lights) on whether X increase in GDP normally means a Y<br>increase in healthcare expenditure. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T16:26:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Max Hotopf</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;522a42a0.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;beba57fa.1503">   <title>FW: job advert: Research Associate - University of Strathclyde - Centre for Health Policy based in the Department of Management Science </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;beba57fa.1503</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>We are advertising the below position - at http://www.jobs.ac.uk/job/AKQ783/research-associate-15253/ and below - please apply or forward to anyone who might be interested!<br><br>With apologies for cross-posting, and best wishes<br><br>Alec<br><br>Professor Alec Morton<br><br>Professor of Management Science<br>Department of Management Science<br>Strathclyde Business School<br>University of Strathclyde<br>Glasgow, Scotland<br>United Kingdom<br><br>Research Associate (15253)<br>University of Strathclyde - Centre for Health Policy based in the Department of Management Science<br>Location: [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T11:40:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alec Morton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;beba57fa.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;353661e4.1503">   <title>Health Economics, Policy and Law </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;353661e4.1503</link>   <description> Hi,<br><br>The latest issue of Health Economics, Policy and Law is now online.<br><br>This issue starts with original research articles on values in health care priority setting (by Claudia Landwehr and Dorothea Klinnert), on the role of hospital payments in the adoption of new medical technologies (by Corinna Sorenson, Michael Drummond, Aleksandra Torbica, Giuditta Callea and Ceu Mateus), and on preferences for lifestyle interventions to reduce obesity (by Mandy Ryan, Deokhee Yi, Alison Avenell, Flora Douglas, Lorna Aucott, Edwin van Teijlingen and Luke Vale). [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-06T16:53:43+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Oliver,AJ</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;353661e4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;4b87e44d.1503">   <title>Training course on health systems strengthening in Barcelona in April 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;4b87e44d.1503</link>   <description> In case of interest. Apologies for cross posting<br><br>The WHO Regional Office for Europe is pleased to announce the next annual Flagship Course on Health Systems Strengthening to be held from 27 April to 01 May 2015 in Barcelona, Spain. This week-long intensive course is offered by the Division of Health Systems and Public Health of the WHO Regional Office for Europe through the WHO Barcelona Office for Health Systems Strengthening and the Health Policy Analysis Center of Kyrgyzstan. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-03T09:33:24+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Thomson,S</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;4b87e44d.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;20654b35.1502">   <title>FW: Workshop on Public Financing of Long Term Care, LSE, UK, August 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;20654b35.1502</link>   <description> From: Health Economics Distribution Superlist [mailto:HEALTHECON-ALL@JISCMAIL.AC.UK] On Behalf Of Bruce Hollingsworth<br>Sent: 25 February 2015 13:35<br>To: HEALTHECON-ALL@JISCMAIL.AC.UK<br>Subject: Workshop on Public Financing of Long Term Care, LSE, UK, August 2015<br><br>From: Luigi Siciliani &lt;luigi.siciliani@york.ac.uk&lt;mailto:luigi.siciliani@york.ac.uk&gt;&gt;<br>Subject: Workshop on Public Financing of Long Term Care, LSE, UK, August 2015<br><br>http://www.ifs.org.uk/uploads/FS%20call%20for%20papers.pdf<br><br>Fiscal Studies<br>Call for papers: Public Financing of Long Term Care<br>This issue will be edited by Joan Costa-Font (London School of Economics), Thomas Crossley (IFS and Cambridge), Edward Norton (University of Michigan) and Luigi Siciliani (University of York).<br>Since its inception in 1979, Fiscal Studies has earned a reputation around [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T13:40:47+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Mcdaid,D</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;20654b35.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6a6f11f.1502">   <title>Re: Indonesian expert? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6a6f11f.1502</link>   <description> Hi,<br>THE expert on Indonesia is Hilbrand Haak, of chd-consultants.nl &lt;http://chd-consultants.nl/&gt;.<br>Say hello to him from me<br>Sophia<br><br>&gt; On Feb 25, 2015, at 12:30 PM, Max Hotopf &lt;max@HEALTHCAREEUROPA.COM&gt; wrote:<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Hi,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I just wondered if anyone knew an expert on healthcare in Indonesia which we are writing about now?<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Here is an interesting article on how developing World operators are starting to buy private healthcare specialists in Europe. (You'd have thought it would be the other way round but we don't think so.)<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Gulf hospital buys European expertise<br>&gt;<br>&gt; 24/02/15<br>&gt;<br> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T13:56:00+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sophia Schlette</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6a6f11f.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b4258e95.1502">   <title>Indonesian expert? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b4258e95.1502</link>   <description> Hi,<br><br>I just wondered if anyone knew an expert on healthcare in Indonesia which<br>we are writing about now?<br><br>Here is an interesting article on how developing World operators are<br>starting to buy private healthcare specialists in Europe. (You'd have<br>thought it would be the other way round but we don't think so.)<br><br>Gulf hospital buys European expertise<br>24/02/15 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-25T11:30:24+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Max Hotopf</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b4258e95.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;3a99b06d.1502">   <title>Re: The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;3a99b06d.1502</link>   <description> Interesting.<br><br>My UKIP point was about leaving the EU altogether.......!<br><br>But on the more complex stuff: Scotland and Wales are presumably exempt<br>from EU law about economic entities, as they have no purchaser/provider<br>split, no contracting and no price competition. Providers are a function<br>within Health Boards, not entities. A more complex case is England where<br>there is competition but NOT price competition.......ie presumably someone<br>could make a case against applying EU law on that ground (probably<br>unsuccessfully?) Or does there have to be no competition of any sort to<br>keep out private firms, including international ones? [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T18:00:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Calum Paton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;3a99b06d.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c8664725.1502">   <title>Re: The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c8664725.1502</link>   <description> Dear Calum: thanks: just one quick point: it is not English law that<br>determines who or what is an economic entity, but the very nature of the<br>activity of that entity. Anyone providing goods and services against<br>payments over which he or she or it has some sort of influence/can bargain,<br>is seen as an economic activity, and therefore the entity is an undertaking<br>in competition law, and therefore an undertaking, and therefore exposed to<br>EU competition law. If governments want to keep a sector outside that<br>field, they will have to exclude it fully from price competition and set<br> [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T12:48:16-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Kieke Okma</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c8664725.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a103b544.1502">   <title>Re: The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a103b544.1502</link>   <description> Yes, Kieke, a good point. EU law might force the English NHS to have open<br>tendering IF English law has providers as 'economic entities' as opposed to<br>'state administrative entities'. (It might, but then it might<br>not....depends on the politics of the EU and its judiciary at the time!?)<br>Therefore IF Labour won and wanted to have the NHS as preferred provider,<br>it might have to go the whole hog and end tendering altogether (ie not<br>NHS-only tendering, with competition between NHS Trusts.) Then England<br>might have to copy Scotland and Wales and re-integrate the NHS as opposed<br>to waffling [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T17:27:52+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Calum Paton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a103b544.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;aee7e75c.1502">   <title>Re: The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;aee7e75c.1502</link>   <description> Hi Calum: wouldn't this be a case where government does not really have a<br>choice because of EU competition law? National governments can set the<br>overall directions of their health policies, but once they decide to open<br>the field to competition by tendering that allows providers and third<br>parties to negotiate over prices and volumes of services, governments have<br>very limited power to restrict the market behaviors. They cannot allow a<br>bit of the market to act and then decide to give a preferential position to<br>government agencies after all (or to national entities for that matter as<br>EU law [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T12:04:56-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Kieke Okma</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;aee7e75c.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b9d7f8f3.1502">   <title>HEPL 10th Anniversary event, October 22nd from 6-7.45pm at the LSE </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b9d7f8f3.1502</link>   <description> An event to mark the 10th anniversary of Health Economics Policy and Law will take place at the London School of Economics from 6.00-7.45pm on October 22nd. The programme will begin with some words about HEPL from Patrick McCartan of Cambridge University Press.<br><br>There will then be short statements from some of the members of HEPL's International Advisory Board on what they think the biggest challenges will be in health care policy, either from the perspective of their own country or internationally, over the next 10 years. The presenters reflect the mix of disciplinary perspectives on which HEPL focuses (i.e. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-16T13:07:11+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Adam Oliver</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;b9d7f8f3.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;53eecc77.1502">   <title>Health Economics, Policy and Law </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;53eecc77.1502</link>   <description> An event will take place to mark the 10th anniversary of HEPL at the LSE on the evening of October 22nd, accompanied by an anniversary special issue of the journal. The programme will be available in due course, but will consist of some round table discussion, a public lecture etc. on issues pertaining to the focus of the journal. It'll be free to attend, but places will be limited to some extent. Since diaries fill up quickly, you can book a place now if you wish. We hope to see you there, and we hope the event will provide a [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-11T23:22:37+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Adam Oliver</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;53eecc77.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;481ee5e6.1502">   <title>Re: EHPG meeting Krakow 23 & 24 April 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;481ee5e6.1502</link>   <description> Dear EHPG Members,<br>In addition to the information sent by Dr Jan-Kees Helderman please find attached information about accommodation. The Organizing Committee has made a preliminary reservation for the conference participants in the hotels listed in the table placed on pages 3 and 4 of the attached document.<br>In order to make the hotel reservation, please contact the hotel directly by e-mail or phone (until the indicated deadline). While asking for a room availability please give the conference code: EHPG. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-10T11:32:24+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Katarzyna Kissimova-Skarbek</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;481ee5e6.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;5487cb95.1502">   <title>EHPG meeting Krakow 23 & 24 April 2015 </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;5487cb95.1502</link>   <description> Dear EHPG members,<br><br>The 2015-Spring EHPG meeting will be organized in Krakow (Poland) on 23 &amp; 24 April 2015 at Jagiellonian University Medical College, Faculty of Health Sciences, Institute of Public Health. Participants can choose between a basic fee of 450 PLN (including dinner but excluding the tour) or a full fee of 500 PLN (including the tour). For accompanying persons, the basic fee is 200 PLN (dinner only) or 250 PLN (dinner and tour). [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-09T15:46:16+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Jan-Kees Helderman</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;5487cb95.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;93182f52.1502">   <title>What role should think-tanks play? </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;93182f52.1502</link>   <description> Adam asked this question a few weeks back now - apologies for cross-posting<br>to both sites, as I can't recall on which one....<br><br>I was reminded of it when the King's Fund in London yesterday (February 6th<br>2015) published its report (Part 1) on the Lansley reforms to the English<br>NHS (begun in 2010 and named after the Conservative former Health<br>Secretary) , which led to the Health and Social Care Act 2012, which in<br>turn created the architecture which has been bamboozling the English NHS<br>for the last two or three years. Architecture? I don't think the Prince of<br> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-02-07T11:39:55+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Calum Paton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;93182f52.1502</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;724a7888.1501">   <title>The UK general election and the row over Labour's health policy in England </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;724a7888.1501</link>   <description> There is currently a row within the Labour Party in the UK, with the<br>general election approaching, over English health policy. So-called<br>Blairites such as former Health Secretary (1999-2003) Alan Milburn have<br>attacked party policy to make the NHS the 'preferred provider' as opposed<br>to having mandatory tendering of every service, open to private providers<br>both national and international. That is, Milburn and others seem to<br>support the Health and Social Care Act of 2012, following former<br>Conservative Health Secretary (2010-2012) Andrew Lansley's White paper of<br>2010. It is Labour policy to repeal this. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-30T20:12:39+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Calum Paton</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;724a7888.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6884992f.1501">   <title>Re: 7 day working </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6884992f.1501</link>   <description> There is another attempt about to get underway in Australia to reduce terms and conditions of employees across all industries. The hospitality industry won a marginal reduction in weekend 'penalty' rates about three months ago, and a new review of industrial relations will also address this issue. I think it will probably not go very far. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-23T19:07:37+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Stephen Duckett</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;6884992f.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c906594a.1501">   <title>7 day working </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c906594a.1501</link>   <description> Interested in other countries experiences of 7 day working and how you remunerate staff. Any answers to the following gratefully received...<br><br>* Does your country operate (publicly funded) health services across the seven day week (even if only parts of the service), or are seeking to?<br><br>* Do you have any information about remuneration, including whether there have been any changes (or attempts at or plans to seek changes) in terms and conditions linked to moving to seven day services? (All staff groups) [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-23T18:29:43+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dixon, Anna</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;c906594a.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;121a2cc7.1501">   <title>Re: EHPG Spring meeting 2015 in Krakow </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;121a2cc7.1501</link>   <description> Dear EHPG members, A happy and inspiring year for all of you! If you wish to inspire others as well, then please consider my reminder of the Call for paper-abstracts for our EHPG Spring meeting in Krakow on 23 and 24 April 2015. We have already received a couple of interesting abstracts, but need some more paper proposals to fill this meeting. The theme of the meeting will be 'evaluation of public policies in healthcare' which could cover examples of different approaches and methods of policy evaluation (ranging from randomized controlled experiments to responsive evaluation and experimentalist governance), but also [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-06T19:05:49+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Helderman, J.K. (Jan-Kees)</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;121a2cc7.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a2e18ba6.1501">   <title>Re: KF pushes ACOs </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a2e18ba6.1501</link>   <description> I recently had a paper rejected from a prestigious economics journal because the editor said the manuscript was too scholarly. I kind of liked that. Maybe he was just being polite, but the hope that some of us had that economics would broaden out a bit and perhaps return to its political economy roots following the financial crisis doesn't seem to have materialised. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-06T09:27:04+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Adam Oliver</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;a2e18ba6.1501</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;e7f9e1c5.1501">   <title>Re: KF pushes ACOs </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;e7f9e1c5.1501</link>   <description> Dear colleagues:<br><br>You might have a look at this, from the New York Times:<br><br>http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/06/us/health-care-fixes-backed-by-harvards-experts-now-roil-its-faculty.html?action=click&amp;contentCollection=Pro%20Basketball&amp;module=MostEmailed&amp;version=Full&amp;region=Marginalia&amp;src=me&amp;pgtype=article<br><br>And at this, from Drew Altman of Kaiser Family Foundation:<br><br>http://kff.org/health-costs/perspective/health-cost-growth-is-down-or-not-it-depends-who-you-ask/<br><br>And then tell me why I should believe that the U.S. health policy<br>establishment would ever support giving the U.S. public anything<br>approaching what the average person would understand as &quot;affordable health<br>care.&quot; [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-01-05T23:47:21-05:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Joseph White</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=EHPG;e7f9e1c5.1501</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
